title: Thesis defence
text:
Outline

Introduction to cosmology and the CMB (20-25 min)
Reconstruction of CMB maps (5 min)
Polarisation maps from the ground (15 min)
Other work and conclusion (5-10 min)

title: Thesis defence
text:
Let’s start here, on Earth. Our planet is part of the Solar System, and orbits the Sun. The Sun is one of approximately 400 billion stars in our Galaxy, the Milky Way.
Our Galaxy is a disk so large that it takes light about 100,000 years to travel from one end to the other. As vast as the Milky Way is, it is only one of a trillion galaxies in our observable Universe.
Before astronomical telescopes, only a few nearby galaxies could be seen from Earth. But as soon as we could make detailed observations of other galaxies, astronomers noticed something strange: Distant galaxies are moving away from us.


Credit: ESO/L.Calçada/spaceengine.org

title: Thesis defence
text:
Expansion

We can measure that through an effect called redshifting.
1920s: astronomers measure redshifts of several distant galaxies. The farther away the galaxy, the faster it recedes from us.
Plot distance vs redshift = Hubble diagram (modern version on figure). Used to measure expansion rate of the Universe.
Expected if all galaxies are moving away from each other = U expanding in every direction.
Here is how that kind of uniform expansion works. Say you have a spring and stretch it out. The two closest spirals went from being 1 mm apart to 1 cm apart, but the ends have gone from 1 cm to 50 in the same amount of time! They started further apart, so they moved apart faster.
Because of the relation between how distant a galaxy is and how fast it is receding from us, we use redshift to talk about distances. But because light takes time to travel to us from distant galaxies, we also use redshift as a way to talk about time. A galaxy with a high redshift is not only far away from us in space, it’s also far away in time: its light has taken billions of years to reach us.
Cosmology gives us an opportunity to see the history of our Universe directly. We see stars as they were tens or hundreds of years ago, and other galaxies as they were millions or billions of years ago. Can we look so far away and into the past that we see the Big Bang itself? The answer is yes.




Redshift = wavelength of light stretched as galaxy moves away
Distance-redshift relation: farther away = faster away
The Universe is expanding in every direction!
Finite speed of light: look back in time

High redshift = far away in space and in time.




Modern Hubble diagram using supernovae [Riess et al 2016]

title: Thesis defence
text:
Hot Big Bang = Universe was smaller in the past.
Reverse the expansion: everything was compressed into a very small space. Universe so dense, ordinary matter could not exist. Ultra-dense hot plasma of elementary particles.
Now the expansion starts. Formal description = standard cosmological model (based on GR).
Nuclear reactions happening everywhere, forming the first atomic nuclei -> nucleosynthesis. Photons constantly bouncing off protons and electrons, cannot travel very far.
Universe keeps expanding. Eventually, after about 380,000 years, the plasma has become cool enough for the first atoms to form, in a process called recombination. The Universe becomes transparent, and the photons are able to travel freely, carrying with them a snapshot of the primordial Universe.
This afterglow of the Big Bang is called the cosmic microwave background (CMB). From our perspective, these photons seem to come from a spherical region that we call the surface of last-scattering. This is the most distant surface of light that we can see, since beyond that the Universe is opaque.
After recombination, apart from the CMB, the Universe remained dark for a while (200 million years) because there were no stars yet. However, the matter was not distributed uniformly.
While the Universe kept expanding, denser regions attracted more matter, and became hotter. Hot enough to eventually trigger nuclear fusion and form the first stars, and then galaxies, clusters of galaxies, and so on.
A few billion years ago, the expansion of the Universe started to accelerate, driven by a mysterious component that we call dark energy. It is still accelerating today.


Credit: NASA (https://science.nasa.gov/universe/overview/).

title: Thesis defence
section: A witness of the homogeneous early universe
text:
A witness of the homogeneous early universe

Let’s come back to the CMB.
There is another clue why the light really is from the primordial plasma. It has to do with its spectrum, which is the intensity of light at different wavelengths.
In the 1990s, the COBE satellite found that the CMB has a nearly perfect blackbody spectrum, which is what you expect from anything that glows with heat. The fact that the CMB has this spectrum is a strong confirmation of the Big Bang theory.
The peak of the spectrum is determined by the temperature. The temperature of the CMB when it was emitted was about 3000 K, but because of the expansion the light has been redshifted and it is now only 2.7K, in the microwave range, hence the name.
This temperature is remarkably uniform across the sky.


The blackbody spectrum of the CMB (Fixsen 1996 adapted by D. Baumann)

title: Thesis defence
text:
The Horizon Problem

But the fact that the CMB has the same temperature everywhere we look is paradoxical.
The light from 2 opposite points on the LSS “meets” for the first time right now when reaching us. For them to be the same temperature, they must have been in causal contact in the past, but there simply hasn’t been enough time for that.
This is called the horizon problem.


Why is the CMB so homogeneous?
Points at same temperature must have been in causal contact


The horizon problem. Credits: D. Baumann

title: Thesis defence
text:
A solution: cosmic inflation

Inflation = phase of accelerated expansion before the standard expansion history.
As illustrated in the figure, inflation is a bit like enlarging a single pixel of an image to fill the entire screen.
This expansion took a causally connected region of space and blew it up to a size bigger than our observable Universe.

Take a causally connected region of space and blow it up to a size bigger than our observable Universe.

Coordinate grid during and after inflation (Dodelson and Schmidt, 2020)

title: Thesis defence
text:
Successes of inflation

Simplest way to achieve inflation = scalar field \(\phi\) with potential energy \(V(\phi)\) >> kinetic energy. ‘Slow-roll’ inflation.
Most impressive feature = mechanism to generate initial conditions for structure formation. Quantum fluctuations \(\delta\phi\) cause different regions of space to inflate by slightly different amounts. Leads to inhomogeneities of density at the end of inflation, which later grow under the influence of gravity to form galaxies and other structures.
Beam of observational evidence agreeing with predictions of single-field slow-roll inflation.


Slow-roll inflation: \(\phi\) with potential energy \(V(\phi) \gg\) kinetic energy.
Quantum fluctuations \(\delta\phi\) -> seeds of cosmic structure!
Measurements agree with slow-roll predictions: adiabatic, nearly scale-invariant perturbations, etc.


Scalar field evolution in slow-roll inflation (source).

title: Thesis defence
text:
Primordial gravitational waves

But “Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.”
Very clean prediction of inflation: primordial gravitational waves.
Follow slide text.
Moreover, primordial GWs leave a unique imprint that we can look for in the CMB!


Quantum fluctuations -> perturbations of metric tensor (space-time)
Amplitude of perturbations as a function of size

scalar: \(\Delta^2_s(k) = A_s (k/k_*)^{n_s - 1}\)
tensor: \(\Delta^2_t(k) = A_t (k/k_*)^{n_t}\)

Tensor perturbations = gravitational waves (GWs)
Tensor-to-scalar ratio: \[
r \equiv A_t / A_s \propto E^4_\mathrm{inf}
\]
Insight into the fundamental laws of Physics at very high energies


GWs leave a unique imprint in the CMB!

title: Thesis defence
text:
Discovery

The CMB was discovered by accident in 1965 by Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson, working at Bell Labs in New Jersey.
Experimenting with a very sensitive horn antenna (figure) for trans-atlantic communication (using balloons to echo signal).
Residual excess noise in all directions of the sky, perfectly consistent with predictions of uniform background of microwaves left over from the Big Bang.
Nobel Prize in Physics in 1978.


“A measurement of excess antenna temperature at 4080 Mc/s” (Penzias and Wilson, 1965)
“Cosmic Black-Body Radiation” (Dicke, Peebles, Roll and Wilkinson, 1965)


Penzias and Wilson on the Holmdel Horn Antenna (source).

title: Thesis defence
text:
Temperature anisotropies

Experiments to measure CMB in more detail, try to find anisotropies.
Comment on figure. Remove average brightness -> find dipole (motion of Earth). Remove dipole -> see anisotropies!
Inflationary paradigm: relate anisotropies to initial perturbations. Overdense regions: gravity tries to compress, radiation pressure pushes back -> acoustic oscillations in the plasma.
At last-scattering, photons coming from different regions have slightly different energy -> anisotropies.
A major contributor to the first measurement of these anisotropies was George Smoot. Associated with APC for a long time, passed away a few days ago.



The CMB is not perfectly uniform!

Monopole (average temperature)

\(T \sim 2.7\,\mathrm{K}\)

Dipole (motion of the Earth)

\(\Delta T / T \sim 1 / 1000\)

Anisotropies (acoustic oscillations in the plasma)

\(\Delta T / T \sim 10^{-5}\)





George Smoot






COBE-DMR maps of the sky (monopole, dipole, anisotropies). Credit: NASA/COBE Science Team

title: Thesis defence
text:
Increasingly precise measurements

In the early 2000s, many experiments especially ground-based and balloon-borne improved the sensitivity and angular resolution of anisotropy measurements. But during two decades, it was two satellite missions that fuelled much of the progress in CMB science: WMAP and Planck.
Comment on the figure. Remarkable agreement between theory and power spectrum measurements.


CMB anisotropies in a 10 square degrees sky patch, seen by three generations of satellites: COBE-DMR (1989-1993), WMAP (2001-2010) and Planck (2009-2013). Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/ESA.

title: Thesis defence
text:
Angular power spectrum

CMB anisotropies are noise (acoustic oscillations) -> spectral properties.
Temporal frequency for sound -> angular (spatial frequency) for CMB maps.
Formally: spherical harmonic decomposition of the fluctuations.
Power spectrum = variance of fluctuations at each angular scale.


How to characterise “noise”? Look at its spectral properties.
Spatial/angular frequency: multipole moment \(\ell\) – angular scale \(\theta \sim 2\pi / \ell\)
Power spectrum \(C_\ell\) = variance of fluctuations at scale \(\ell\)


Planck power spectrum of temperature fluctuations along with best-fit model (Credit: ESA and the Planck Collaboration)

title: Thesis defence
text:
Basics of polarisation

Light is polarised when its electric field oscillates preferentially in a given direction (example below).
The CMB is polarised through Thomson scattering of photons off free electrons in the primordial plasma. The efficiency of this process depends on the angle between the incoming and outgoing polarisation directions.
To characterise linear polarisation, we use the Stokes parameters \(I\), \(Q\) and \(U\).
The same way as temperature maps, we can make Q and U maps of the sky.




Thomson scattering \(\propto \lvert \hat\epsilon \cdot \hat\epsilon' \rvert^2\)
3 Stokes parameters entirely describe linear polarisation

\(I\) = total intensity (temperature)
\(Q\) = difference in brightness between horizontal and vertical
\(U\) = difference in brightness between +45° and -45°





Vertically polarised electromagnetic wave (source)






Credit: Emma Alexander (source)

title: Thesis defence
text:
\(E\) and \(B\) modes

Polarisation field = headless vector.
Figure: polarisation field on top of total intensity map from Planck.
Q and U depend on coordinate system. Decomposition into \(E\) (parity-even) and \(B\) (parity-odd) patterns.
\(E\) and \(B\) related to physical processes in the plasma.
Remarkably, \(B\) modes are only sourced by tensor perturbations, GWs! (at first order)
By measuring CMB polarisation, specifically B modes, we have access to \(r\) and inflation.






CMB polarisation superimposed on temperature map (smoothed to 5°) (Planck 2018 results I)






\(B\) modes are only sourced by tensor perturbations!
By measuring CMB polarisation, we have access to \(r\) and inflation

title: Thesis defence
text:
Current constraints on \(r\)

For now, no detection of primordial \(B\) modes has been made. We only have upper limits on the value of \(r\).
The best constraint to date is from the BICEP/Keck collaboration combined with Planck data.
The figure on the right shows measurements of \(B\)-mode power spectrum from various experiments.
Target either recombination bump (\(\ell \approx 100\)) or reionisation bump (\(\ell \lt 10\)).
In both cases we need a measurement of the CMB polarisation at intermediate to large scales.






Compilation of \(r\) constraints (Tristram et al., 2022)


Best: \(r < 0.032\) at 95% confidence




Summary of \(B\)-mode polarisation measurements (BK 2021)

title: Thesis defence
text:
The Simons Observatory

Measuring \(r\) is one of the main science goals of the Simons Observatory.
The observatory is located in the Atacama desert in Chile, which is high and dry, ideal for millimetre-wave observations. SO builds on decades of experience in observing CMB from the ground.
It comprises three small aperture telescopes (SATs) dedicated to the measurement of large scale polarisation. A large aperture telescope (LAT) will observe smaller scales (high resolution) over a large fraction of the sky.
Very broad science case, from inflation to neutrino mass and number of relativistic species, etc. But the main goal for the SATs is to reach \(\sigma(r) = 0.002\).
To meet these ambitious goals, SO has deployed about 60,000 detectors over 6 frequency bands. Observations have started since last year, and we are analysing the data now!




Cerro Toco, Chile, 5200m altitude (“high and dry”)
3 small (SATs) + 1 large aperture telescopes (LAT)
LAT for small scales over large sky fraction
SATs for polarisation at degree scales

baseline \(\sigma(r) = 0.003\) (goal \(0.002\))

60,000+ detectors
6 frequency bands, 27-280 GHz
Data is coming now!




SAT in its ground shield (credit: SO collaboration)






Simons Observatory site on Cerro Toco

title: Thesis defence
text:
From time-ordered data to maps

Start from figure on the right!
Lensing converts \(E\) -> \(B\) and vice versa.
CMB signal is faint: each individual data sample is noise dominated.
To achieve a good sensitivity across a significant sky area, CMB telescopes collect lost of measurements across the targeted area by scanning. This also helps to mitigate low-frequency instrumental noise.
The raw data is therefore made of time series (one/detector) called time-ordered data (TOD).
With knowledge of the scanning strategy (pointing information) we can reconstruct the observed sky maps -> map-making.
It is the first step of several data reduction stages. Huge compression of the data, therefore crucial step to avoid losing information.
Accurate modelling of noise and systematics required.



map-making = from time-ordered data (TOD) to sky maps at observed frequencies
data reduction step: ~6 orders of magnitude




Traditional CMB analysis pipeline steps (credit: Josquin Errard)

title: Thesis defence
text:
Linear data model

Formally: linear data model.
What we recover/know/assume.
Map-making = linear operation.

\[
d = Ps + Tx + n
\]

we know \(d\) (the data)
we estimate \(s\) (sky maps) and marginalize over \(x\) (spurious signals)
we model \(P\) (pointing) and \(T\) (templates)
we assume that \(n\) (noise) has covariance \(N\)

“Map-making” = linear operation \(\hat s = L d\) to estimate sky maps from the data.

title: Thesis defence
text:
Unbiased estimators

Weighted co-addition of the data with spurious signals filtered out.

Generic linear unbiased estimator [Poletti et al. 2017] \[
\hat s = (P^\top F_T P)^{-1} P^\top F_T d
\]
with filtering and weighting operator \[
F_T = W \left[\mathbb I - T (T^\top W T)^{-1} T^\top W \right]
\]

filters out unwanted signals (columns of \(T\))
weights orthogonal modes by weight matrix \(W\)

Minimum variance (optimal) if \(W = N^{-1}\) (generalized least squares, GLS).

title: Thesis defence
text:
Practical considerations

Size of the problem

1,000 detectors + months of data + sampling @100 Hz -> \(n_t \sim 10^{11}\) samples!
resolution + sky coverage + Stokes (I)QU -> \(n_p \sim 10^5 - 10^8\) sky pixels
Numerical efficiency is key!




Noise correlations \(N\) (size \(n_t \times n_t\))

split data in chunks (trade-off efficiency/quality)
assume noise is stationary in each chunk, \(N(t,t')=N(\lvert t-t' \rvert)\)
characterise in Fourier space (power spectral density, PSD)





Iterative solvers

can not compute/store matrices too large
\(\hat s = A^{-1} b\) -> instead solve \(A s = b\)
preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) algorithm
convergence speed influenced by noise correlations

title: Thesis defence
text:
Observing from the ground

Major challenge for map-making from the ground: atmospheric emission.
Dual-polarisation -> intuitive technique to recover polarisation = pair differencing.




Major challenge: atmosphere

much brighter than CMB
loading: increase detector noise
spatial + temporal variations
negligible linear polarisation

Hardware solutions

dual-polarisation detectors
fast polarisation modulation (HWP)







Credit: SO collaboration.






HWP illustration (source).







Emission spectrum of the atmosphere for different levels of PWV. Credit: Morris et al. 2022





Atmosphere simulation. Credit: R. Keskitalo & J. Borrill

title: Thesis defence
text:
Unbiased polarisation map-making

Total intensity \(I\) hard to recover from the ground because of atmosphere.
Focus on polarisation instead; temperature large scales already very well measured from space (Planck).
Compare DW and PD and see how they manage to take advantage of hardware solutions.

Focus on unbiased reconstruction of polarisation (\(Q\) and \(U\)).

Minimal model

no specific temporal or spatial structure
unpolarised atmosphere identical for orthogonal detectors

Down-weighting (DW)

\(W = (N_\mathrm{atm} + N_\mathrm{instr})^{-1}\)
stationary noise, independent between detectors

Ideal reconstruction

atmosphere-free data: \(d = P s + n\) (instr. noise only)
GLS solution with \(W = N_\mathrm{instr}^{-1}\)
benchmark tool

title: Thesis defence
text:
Pair differencing

Write down minimal model for one pair of detectors.
Use template filtering to estimate \(Q\) and \(U\), marginalising over \(x\).
Find pair differencing!

Minimal model for pair of orthogonal detectors: \[
d = \begin{bmatrix} d_\parallel \\ d_\perp \end{bmatrix}
    = \begin{bmatrix} T \\ T \end{bmatrix} x
    + \begin{bmatrix} P_{QU} \\ -P_{QU} \end{bmatrix} s_{QU}
    + \begin{bmatrix} n_\parallel \\ n_\perp \end{bmatrix}
\]
GLS template filtering estimator gives \[
\hat s_{QU} = (P_{QU}^\top N_-^{-1} P_{QU})^{-1} P_{QU}^\top N_-^{-1} d_-
\] with \(d_- \equiv d_\parallel - d_\perp\) and \(N_-\) the covariance of \(n_- \equiv n_\parallel - n_\perp\).
Minimal model equivalent to pair-differencing (PD).

title: Thesis defence
text:
Questions

How do DW and PD compare out of the box?
How far is PD from the ideal reconstruction?
What is the impact of systematic effects?

title: Thesis defence
text:
Numerical simulations

To answer these questions, I performed advanced time-domain simulations of an SO-like small aperture telescope.
I used the toast simulation framework and adjusted it for the needs of the study.
In particular I implemented the interface between toast and our reconstruction library, mappraiser (see figure).
Massively parallel implementation of the unbiased map-making estimator presented earlier, which I developed further.

title: Thesis defence
text:
Results: PD vs DW

In the absence of systematics, PD is nearly optimal.
No need/reason to try and improve beyond that, unless a better model of atmosphere is available.
How precise is PD compared to ideal reconstruction (perfect model)?




different models, different assumptions
implicit differencing in DW (\(W_\parallel = W_\perp\)) necessary to avoid atmosphere leakage




Noise power spectra compared to reference.






Noise maps from PD (top) and DW (bottom) with 10% variation of noise parameters.

title: Thesis defence
text:
Results: PD map sensitivity

White noise -> analytical estimate of the noise level in the maps.
PD ideal if identical noise properties. Perturb the nominal noise model and see how much we lose.
Figure: excess variance in \(Q/U\) maps as a function of the variation of noise levels.



White instrumental noise.

How much degradation if \(\sigma_\parallel \neq \sigma_\perp\)?
Excess variance depends on \(\varepsilon \equiv \frac{\sigma_\parallel^2 - \sigma_\perp^2}{\sigma_\parallel^2 + \sigma_\perp^2}\)
Suboptimal propagation of noise levels after differencing





Analytical prediction (black) vs measured excess variance.



\(\hat s^\mathrm{ideal}_{QU} = s^\mathrm{pd}_{QU} + \left( P^\top_- \Pi_{--} P_- \right)^{-1} P^\top_- \Pi_{-+} n_+\)

title: Thesis defence
text:
Results: impact on \(r\)

How do these results translate in terms of \(r\) sensitivity?
Remarkably little impact given the very general assumption behind PD.


25 realisations of realistic instrumental \(1/f\) noise
detector-dependent parameters (knee, slope, white level)
noise power spectrum \(N_\ell^{BB}\) from reconstructed maps \(\hat s^\mathrm{pd}_{QU}\)
Fisher forecast: \[
\sigma(r=0) \approx \frac{f_\text{sky}}{2} \times \sum_{\text{bins $b$}} \delta_\ell (2\ell_b+1) \Bigg( \frac{C_{\ell_b}^{BB,\text{prim}} \rvert_{r=1}}{C_{\ell_b}^{BB,\text{lens}} + \langle N_{\ell_b}^{BB} \rangle} \Bigg)^2
\]

Moderate increase of error bars for typical 10% variation of parameters.

What is JAX
From the JAX website:

JAX is a library for array-oriented numerical computation (à la NumPy), with automatic differentiation and JIT compilation to enable high-performance machine learning research.

Key features

NumPy-like interface with CPU/GPU/TPU support in local and distributed environments
Just-in-time (JIT) compilation via Open XLA
Automatic differentiation
Automatic vectorization

PyTrees
FURAX relies on PyTrees to represent the data.

Example: random sky with 3 components
sky = {
  'cmb': HealpixLandscape(nside, 'IQU').normal(key1),
  'dust': HealpixLandscape(nside, 'IQU').normal(key2),
  'synchrotron': HealpixLandscape(nside, 'IQU').normal(key3),
}
HealpixLandscape(nside, 'IQU') returns an instance of StokesIQUPyTree, a container for the Stokes parameters I, Q, U.


Use FrequencyLandscape to generalize to multiple frequencies.
frequencies = np.array([93, 145])
sky = {
  'cmb': FrequencyLandscape(nside, frequencies, 'IQU').normal(key1),
  'dust': FrequencyLandscape(nside, frequencies, 'IQU').normal(key2),
  'synchrotron': FrequencyLandscape(nside, frequencies, 'IQU').normal(key3),
}

Algebraic reductions: Rotations
Classic acquisition model with ideal linear polarizer \(\mathbf{M}_{\textrm{LP}}\), ideal half wave plate \(\mathbf{M}_{\textrm{HWP}}\), rotations \(\mathbf{R}\), pointing matrix \(\mathbf P\):
\[
\mathbf{H} = \mathbf{M}_{\textrm{LP}} \, \mathbf{R}_{2\theta} \, \mathbf{R}_{-2\phi} \,
\mathbf{M}_{\textrm{HWP}} \, \mathbf{R}_{2\phi} \, \mathbf{R}_{2\psi} \, \mathbf{P}
\]
where

\(\theta\): polarizer angle
\(\phi\): half-wave plate angle
\(\psi\): telescope angle

is reduced automatically to the much simpler
\[
\mathbf{H} = \mathbf{M}_{\textrm{LP}} \, \mathbf{R}_{-2\theta + 4\phi + 2\psi}\, \mathbf{P}
\]

CMB Applications

 Credits: Ema Tsang, Wassim Kabalan, Amalia Villarrubia & the whole SciPol team

Generalized Map-Making



Classic data model
\[
d = \mathbf{P}s + n
\]

\(d\): time-ordered data
\(\mathbf{P}\): pointing matrix (telescope scanning)
\(s\): discretized sky signal
\(n\): stochastic contribution (noise)


Optimal (GLS) solution
\[
\widehat{s} = (\mathbf{P}^\top \mathbf{N}^{-1} \mathbf{P})^{-1} \mathbf{P}^\top \mathbf{N}^{-1} d
\]


Generalized parametric data model





\[
d_{\nu, i, t} = \int_{\textrm{BP}_\nu} d\nu' \mathbf{M}^{(\gamma)}_{\nu', i, t, p} \mathbf{A}^{(\beta)}_{\nu', t, c, p} s_{c, p} + n_{\nu, i, t}
\]

\(\mathbf{M}\): instrument matrix (pointing, HWP parameters, bandpasses, beam properties, etc.)
\(\mathbf{A}\): mixing matrix (modeling of CMB, astrophysical foregrounds, atmosphere, etc.)
\(\mathbf{H} = \mathbf{MA}\) is the generalized pointing operator

Time-domain noise correlations


Noise correlations in a stationary period correspond to a symmetric Toeplitz matrix structure.

easy access to gradients and hessians

Beyond fgbuster

Automatic cluster detection for spectral index parameters
Very flexible model: straight-forward extensions to other sky components, different objective functions, etc.



Cost of evaluating the likelihood function is reduced by a factor 10 for \(\textrm{nside} \geq 64\). 


This will power the map-based pipeline for \(r\) estimation in SO (cf. presentation by Baptiste Jost earlier today).




Credit: Wassim Kabalan

Atmosphere decontamination: time-domain component separation
Goal: For the Simons Observatory, characterize the observed atmospheric template from the recorded time-ordered data to separate the atmosphere from the sky signal we are after.


Detector array scanning the sky (signal has arbitrary units)






Data Model
\[
d_{\text{atm}} = \mathbf{A}(\text{pwv}) \mathbf{P}(\vec{w}) s_{\text{atm}} + n
\]
with parameters:

Wind velocity: \(\vec{w} = (w_x, w_y)\)
Precipitable Water Vapour (PWV): ~Amplitude of atmospheric fluctuations.

Estimate parameters by minimizing the spectral likelihood.
\[
\boxed{
\langle \delta \mathcal{S}_\text{spec}(\vec{w}, \text{pwv} \mid d_{\text{atm}}) \rangle
= d_{\text{atm}}^\top \cdot \mathbf{AP}
\Big[ (\mathbf{AP})^\top \mathbf{N}^{-1} (\mathbf{AP}) \Big]^{-1}
(\mathbf{AP})^\top \mathbf{N}^{-1} d_{\text{atm}}
}
\]




Credit: Amalia Villarrubia Aguilar

Atmosphere decontamination: spectral likelihood minimization



Spectral likelihood values in the \((w_x, w_y)\) plane for a fixed PWV value. 

Minimization is done by brute force: we compute \(\langle \delta \mathcal{S}_\text{spec}(w_x, w_y \mid \text{pwv}_{\text{sim}}) \rangle\) for 22,500 different combinations of \((w_x, w_y)\).
Proof of concept: we can recover the wind parameters!
Future work:

make the likelihood smooth (differentiable) by interpolating the pointing matrix coefficients
use a gradient-based minimization algorithm




Credit: Amalia Villarrubia Aguilar

Conclusion

CMB polarization analysis mixes instrument + foregrounds + cosmology
Need for robust and efficient tools
We are building a python-based toolbox

using jax for performance and portability
able to represent complex instrument models

Applications: map-making, component separation, atmosphere decontamination, etc.
Goals for early 2025

unbiased map-making + map-based pipeline for SO-SAT
cluster component separation for LiteBIRD


If you are interested, check out our the repository on GitHub: CMBSciPol/furax.
This work is part of the ERC project SciPol (https://scipol.in2p3.fr/).
